<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_IdleLoop_Impl:
```c
void OS_IdleLoop_Impl(void)
{
    /*
     * Unblock signals and wait for something to occur
     *
     * Note - "NormalSigMask" was calculated during task init to be the original signal mask
     * of the process PLUS all "RT" signals.  The RT signals are used by timers, so we want
     * to keep them masked here (this is different than the original POSIX impl).  The
     * timebase objects have a dedicated thread that will be doing "sigwait" on those.
     */
    sigsuspend(&POSIX_GlobalVars.NormalSigMask);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_IdleLoop_Impl:
void OS_IdleLoop()
{
    /*
     * Wait until the shutdown value is set to the shutdown number
     * In most "real" embedded systems, this will never happen.
     * However it will happen in debugging situations (CTRL+C, etc).
     */
    while (OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState != OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER)
    {
        OS_IdleLoop_Impl();
    }
}
...
void OS_Application_Run(void)
{
    OS_IdleLoop();
}

        UT_SetHandlerFunction(FuncKey, DefaultHandler, NULL);
    }

    UT_DefaultStubImpl(FunctionName, FuncKey, 0, NULL);

explanation: Only fragments that perform function calls or can cause control to transfer into handlers are relevant for checking indirect/self-recursion. The sigsuspend call in OS_IdleLoop_Impl is the primary point of concern because it can return due to a signal and signal handlers (not shown) may call back into OS_IdleLoop or OS_IdleLoop_Impl, creating potential indirect recursion. The loop in OS_IdleLoop repeatedly calls OS_IdleLoop_Impl and thus is relevant for investigation to determine if any call chain leads back to these functions. OS_Application_Run simply invokes OS_IdleLoop and is included for completeness as the entry point. UT_ExecuteBasicHandler is included because it installs/executes handler functions (UT_SetHandlerFunction/UT_DefaultStubImpl) which could potentially call back into the same code paths and produce indirect recursion. The remaining items in the provided snippets (e.g. the POSIX_GlobalVars initialization and comment-only lines) do not perform calls and therefore do not need investigation for Rule 17.2.
